title: Tunisia’s Presidential Race Tests Sole Democracy to Emerge From Arab Spring
text:
Two dozen candidates are running in Tunisia’s presidential election. Posters in the capital,Tunis, on Sept. 7.

TUNIS—When the people of Tunisia took to the streets in 2011, their protests set off the Arab Spring, fanning years of rebellion and war across the Middle East. Tunisia was the only country to emerge from that tumult as a democracy.

Today, as new democratic movements gather strength elsewhere in North Africa and Tunisia prepares for a presidential election on Sunday, the country’s role as a showcase for democracy in the volatile region is being tested.

The death in July of the country’s 95-year-old president, who was expected to step down in November, accelerated plans for the election, the country’s second since the uprising that toppled former President Zine El Abidine Ben Ali in January 2011.

The race has been beset by controversy and surprises. The apparent front-runner, a media mogul, was jailed in August in a disputed tax-evasion case but remains on the ballot. The late president’s conservative party has splintered in a rivalry among its former leaders, while the country’s leading moderate Islamist party put forward a nominee for the first time. Two dozen candidates are contesting the wide-open race, including remnants of the old autocratic regime and Tunisia’s first openly gay candidate.

Presidential candidate Abdel-Fattah Mourou, a moderate Islamist lawyer, meeting with supporters in Tunis, on Sept. 9. Photo: fethi belaid/Agence France-Presse/Getty Images

“Success isn’t in the outcome of the election,” said Abdel-Fattah Mourou, a moderate Islamist member of parliament and lawyer who is one of the leading candidates. “Success is that the election is happening.”

While a democratic Tunisia emerged from the 2011 revolts, other countries like Libya, Syria and Yemen remain mired in conflict. In Egypt the military seized power, reverting the country to autocracy. This year, though, protest movements breathed new life into hopes for democracy across the region after the fall of autocrats Omar Bashir in Sudan and Abdelaziz Bouteflika in Algeria.

“There’s quite a lot of tumult,” said Dan Twining, president of the International Republican Institute, an American nongovernmental group that is observing the Tunisian vote. “Citizens are highly dissatisfied and disaffected by dictatorial rule.”

Many credit Tunisia’s success to a spirit of compromise by the country’s disparate political factions, which struck a pact in 2013 to avoid Egypt’s fate. The country also established a truth commission that shed light on past government abuses. The deceased president, Beji Caid Essebsi, guided Tunisia’s transition to democracy despite having been a senior official in the old regime, pursuing legal reforms and bringing his party into a governing coalition with an Islamist party.

Mr. Essebsi didn’t leave a successor in place, and since his death several candidates are competing to claim the secular conservative constituency he represented, among them Prime Minister Youssef Chahed and Defense Minister Abdelkarim Zbidi.

The moderate Islamist party he worked with, Ennahda, nominated Mr. Mourou, after having previously avoided the presidency out of concern over the pressures an Islamist government would face. His candidacy is a reminder of how Tunisia managed to avoid the fate of Egypt, which elected Islamist President Mohammed Morsi in 2012 and then saw its brief experiment with democracy end in a military coup.

“My goal is to deepen democratic institutions,” Mr. Mourou said in an interview.

The first round of the election will be held Sept. 15, with a runoff expected in the following weeks if no candidate wins an outright majority.

Economic issues have played large in the election amid growing disaffection among the Tunisian public, especially the country’s youth, who face an estimated unemployment rate of 35%.

The economy is growing at a sluggish 1.2%, still struggling to recover from a series of terrorist attacks that devastated Tunisia’s tourist industry. Budget cuts and a $2.9 billion loan from the International Monetary Fund have eroded living standards and failed to draw enough foreign investment to spur growth.

“I can’t see anyone I can trust in the candidates,” said Khalil Jegham, a 21-year-old biology student.

Prime Minister Youssef Chahed, a member of the deceased president’s party, is vying with other party rivals for the presidency. Photo: hasna/Agence France-Presse/Getty Images

Tunisians of all stripes have stepped forward to court voters like Mr. Jegham, including businessman Slim Riahi. Mr. Riahi, who was convicted of corruption charges and lives in France, beamed a hologram of himself into one of his campaign events in August.

The front-runner in polls is Nabil Karoui, the owner of a major television channel and other media ventures, who has built support among the poor through handouts of food and promises to restart Tunisia’s economy.

Police arrested Mr. Karoui on Aug. 23, throwing the campaign into chaos and leading to concerns about bias in the country’s judicial institutions and the election’s integrity. However, the election commission has ruled that he is still allowed to stand in the election while the tax case continues.

Mr. Karoui was charged with tax evasion after investigations by an anticorruption nonprofit showed that he was paying relatively little in taxes on his media and advertising empire. His campaign says he is innocent and has accused the government of using the tax case to try to sideline him from the election.

Supporters of jailed presidential candidate Nabil Karoui rally in front of a tribunal in Tunis to ask for his release from prison. Photo: mohamed khalil/Agence France-Presse/Getty Images

Mr. Karoui’s populist campaign captured the frustrations of some ordinary Tunisians who haven’t seen living conditions change since the 2011 uprising. He spent months touring poor, neglected areas of Tunisia, handing out food and offering services like free surgeries through a charity organization he runs.

A Karoui campaign official welcomed comparisons between his candidate and President Trump, citing Mr. Karoui’s plans to restart the economy by easing government restrictions on private businesses. “We’re going to kill the old system,” said Samy Achour, a member of Mr. Karoui’s campaign, outlining plans to change Tunisia’s economy.

Opponents view Mr. Karoui as an aspiring strongman, citing leaked recordings in which he threatened to blackmail anticorruption activists. The candidate has said the recordings were misleadingly edited.

Many Tunisians and close observers worry that the fiercely contested election points to the need to advance the country’s democratic project, including overhauls to the security institutions of the old regime that remain susceptible to autocratic politicians.

“The assessment of the evolution of democracy, and the success of democracy in Tunisia needs to be accompanied with a certain sobriety,” said Patricia Karam, IRI’s regional director for the Middle East and North Africa. “Change comes at a pace that is sometimes slower than what we expect.”

Write to Jared Malsin at jared.malsin@wsj.com

Corrections & Amplifications

Daniel Twining is the president of the International Republican Institute. An earlier version of this article misspelled his surname.
description: Conservatives, Islamists and the country’s first openly gay candidate are running in the country’s second presidential election since the Arab Spring, but the jailing of one candidate has sparked concerns over the election’s political integrity.
